origination.role: The firm of Dixon and Ross was the printer in 1838, but the printer of the c. 1892 sets, such as the one presented here, is not recorded.

imprint.publisher: John Linnell and his familyNeither the cover label nor the plates themselves indicate a publisher, but the Dante engravings were printed for and sold by John Linnell in 1838, and by the Linnell family c. 1892.
imprint.date: noneNo date of publication is given on the cover label or the engravings; see the information below on Printing Date.

objinfo.printdate: 1838, c. 1892 1838 (cover label), c. 1892 (the 7 engravings). The Dante engravings were first printed in 38 complete sets in 1838. A second printing of 50 sets can be dated to c. 1892. The printing date for impressions on the type of paper represented by the set reproduced here cannot be determined with certainty, but they probably are part of the later printing. The cover label, printed in letterpress, probably dates from 1838. Further impressions were pulled from the plates in 1955 (20 sets) and 1968 (25 sets).
objinfo.numberobj: 8The first object is the Dante cover label printed in letterpress; Objects 2-8 are the Dante engravings.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 9.3 x 12.1 cm. (Object 1, the cover label) and 24.2 x 34.0 cm. (Objects 2-8, the engravings)Dimensions recorded here are of the complete image, including printed framing lines.
objinfo.medium: letterpress (Object 1, the cover label), intaglio engravings (Objects 2-8)
objinfo.support: laid paper (Object 1, the cover label), India paper (*chine collee*) on wove paper backing sheets (Objects 2-8)
objinfo.watermark: NThis (fragmentary?) watermark appears only on Objects 2, 6, and 7.
objinfo.framelines: A double frame line surrounds the cover label (Object 1). An engraved line, contiguous with the edges of the image, surrounds each engraved designs (Objects 2-8) on all four sides.

provenance.name: Robert N. Essick
provenance.note: Sold Sotheby's, 11 July 1974, lot 17A, "the property of a lady" (£3700 to Andrew Edmunds acting for Robert N. Essick). Earlier history unknown.

objnote.p: This is a title label, printed in letterpress, originally pasted to a cover sheet or folder housing the engravings.

lg.l: Seven Plates, designed and engraved by W. BLAKE, Author of "Illustrations of
...and like a corse fell to the ground.
And mangled bore away the sinewy part.
He ey'd the serpent and the serpent him.

desc.objtitle:
The Circle of the Lustful: Francesca Da Rimini The Whirlwind of Lovers, and like a corse fell to the ground,
object 2 (Bentley 448.1)

objnote.p: The engraving is based on Blake's water color, The Circle of the Lustful: Francesca Da Rimini, Butlin 812.10.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A bank or ledge covered in vines or roots appears in the right half of the design. A whirlwind of water or fire(?) rises from the lower right to the upper left corner; the column forms a single loop. A second column, more clearly of fire, rises above the bank, extending up and to the left. The sun appears in the upper right corner; beams of light radiate outward. Two nude figures kneel within the disc of the sun in the upper right corner of the design. The female(?) figure to the right is seen from behind. The figures are likely kissing. They probably represent Francesca da Rimini (on the right?) and Paolo Malatesta (on the left?). A gowned male representing Virgil stands on the ledge. Virgil has long hair and his head is turned down; he likely looks toward Dante, below. Virgil's arms are down at his sides and the palms of both hands are turned down. Dante lies supine on the grassy ledge. His body is positioned horizontally with his head to the right. His eyes are closed; he has fainted. Dante's left arm rests on the ground and the palm of his left hand is turned down. Two figures fly or hover within the column above Dante. The figure to the right is a gowned female with long hair. She likely represents Francesca da Rimini. Francesca faces forward with her upper body twisted to the left. Her left arm is bent upward; she reaches for and may touch the male pictured to the left. Francesca's head is turned up and her mouth may be open. Her eyes are raised and she looks at her companion. The figure to the left is a partially nude male with short hair. He likely represents Paolo Malatesta. Paolo is seen from behind with his upper body twisted to the right. Both legs are bent slightly and folds of drapery are visible above his knees. Paolo's right arm is raised at 45 degrees; he reaches for and may touch the female pictured to the right. At least thirty-seven nude figures fly or hover within a large column of water(?) rising from the lower right to the upper left corner of the design. The column forms a single loop and the figures are likely rising upward as if blown by a wind. These figures are often grouped in pairs. Many of the figures are nude or partially nude with twisted bodies and outstretched arms.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell.
A bank or ledge covered in vines or roots appears in the right half of the design. On the bank, one figure, likely Virgil, stands at right while a second figure, likely Dante, lies supine at left.
The bank of ledge in the right half of the design is covered with vegetation, including grass, leaves, roots, and/or vines.

A gowned male representing Virgil stands facing forward on the ledge at right. Virgil has long hair and his head is turned down; he leans slightly to the left. He likely looks toward the supine figure, Dante, below. Virgil's arm are at his sides and the palms of both hands are turned down. His bare feet are visible beneath the hem of his gown.

The second figure on the bank at right, Dante, lies supine. His body is positioned horizontally with his head to the right. He wears a gown and has short hair. His eyes are closed; he has fainted. Dante's left arm rests on the ground and the palm of his left hand is turned down. His bare feet are visible beneath the hem of his gown at left.
The sun with two figures inside it appears in the upper right corner. Beams of light radiate outward across the upper half of the design, suggesting sky.

Two nude figures kneel within the disc of the sun in the upper right corner of the design. The female(?) figure to the right is seen from behind. She may have long hair worn in a braid down her back. Her right arm is bent upward with palm facing out. Her right leg is bent beneath her, and her buttocks are prominent. She faces away but twists to the left to kiss her male companion at left. The figures probably represent Francesca da Rimini (on the right) and Paolo Malatesta (on the left).

Two nude figures kneel within the disc of the sun in the upper right corner of the design. The male figure at left faces left but turns to face forward to kiss his female companion at right. He has short hair and his eyes may be closed. Both arms are bent upward at varying degrees with hands raised, palms facing out. His right leg is bent at 90 degrees and his left knee rests on the ground with his leg bent beneath it. There may be an indistinguishable object just left of his right knee.

A whirlwind of water or fire(?) rises from the lower right to the upper left corner; the column forms a single loop and contains at least thirty-seven figures. Waves are visible in the lower left corner of the composition.
A second column, more clearly of fire, rises above the bank, extending up and to the left, and it contains two figures. This column resemble a tongue of flame.

Two figures fly or hover within the second column above Dante. The figure to the right is a gowned female with long, curly hair that stands on end. She likely represents Francesca da Rimini. Francesca faces forward with her upper body twisted to the left. Her left arm is bent upward; she reaches for and may touch or hold the male figure at left. Her right arm is raised at 135 degrees, palm facing up. Francesca's eyes are raised, perhaps to look toward her companion, and her mouth may be open.

Two figures fly or hover within the second column above Dante. The figure to the left is a partially male figure with short hair who wears a shirt (with a collar?), breeches, and perhaps a swath of drapery around his waist that dangles to his right. He likely represents Paolo Malatesta. Paolo is seen from behind with his upper body twisted to the right to look toward the figure at right. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees; he reaches for and may touch his companion's left arm. His left arm is bent upward with palm facing up. Both legs are extended and bent slightly.

Below the bank at right, five figures swim or float in what appears to be a river that rises upward into a column at left. The two rightmost figures, who are directly below Virgil's feet and only partially visible in the water, both face up. Only the head of the higher figure is visible; its eyes are closed (perhaps suggesting unconsciousness or death?) and its mouth is open. The figure may be drowning.

Below the bank at right, five figures swim or float in what appears to be a river that rises upward into a column at left. The two rightmost figures, who are directly below Virgil's feet and only partially visible in the water, both face up. The lower figure, who is female and may wear a gown, appears supine atop the water. Her right arm is raised overhead, palm up and both legs are extended horizontally at right. Her head is turned slightly to face forward. She may be unconscious, dead, or drowning.

Below the bank at right, five figures swim or float in what appears to be a river that rises upward into a column at left. The third figure from the right just below the supine body of Dante is a female figure who faces forward and up. Her body is horizontal but twisted: she wraps both bent arms around her body with her right arm touching her left shoulder and her left arm touching her right elbow. Her legs are bent upward with her left leg partially extended at right. She has long hair that extends above her head at left. Her head is tilted up and back and her mouth is open, perhaps suggesting pain. She may be nude or partially cover herself with a swath of drapery that extends above her at left.

Below the bank at right, five figures swim or float in what appears to be a river that rises upward into a column at left. Immediately below the contorted female figure, a nude male figure whose body is horizontal faces away but turns his head up and around to look forward with an open mouth that may suggest pain. His hair is short and curly. Both arms may be raised horizontally with palms facing out and fingers spread. Alternatively, his left arm may be raised vertically with right arm extended downward. His legs are extended to the right with feet pointed.

Below the bank at right, five figures swim or float in what appears to be a river that rises upward into a column at left. To the left and partially below the nude male figure, the fifth figure in the group faces forward with her head at left. She has short hair and may wear a ribbon(?) on top of her head or have tendrils of hair extending upward. Her mouth is open and she appears to look down. Although her torso appears to be nude, she may wear drapery over the lower half of her body as it appears to curl in serpentine folds below her legs, which are extended diagonally downward and to the right. Her right arm is bent upward with palm facing outward and fingers spread; her left arm is at her side.

Just right of the point at which the river(?) rises into a column, four figures swim or float in a horizontal line against the lower edge of the design. The rightmost of these is a male(?) figure who has short curly hair. He wears a shirt with a prominent neckline and middle seam. His body is horizontal with his torso twisted to face forward. Both arms are bent upward with hands raised, palms out, and, on his right hand, fingers spread. His mouth is open. His legs are together and extended to the right with the right leg over the left.

Just right of the point at which the river(?) rises into a column, four figures swim or float in a horizontal line against the lower edge of the design. Only the head, shoulders, and upper torso of the figure second from the right are visible, facing forward and leaning left. The figure's long hair suggests she is female; moreover, there may be an indication of breasts. She appears to be nude and positioned horizontally. Her eyes are closed, perhaps suggesting she is dead.

Just right of the point at which the river(?) rises into a column, four figures swim or float in a horizontal line against the lower edge of the design. The third from the right is a nude female figure with long, perhaps curly hair who faces forward with an open mouth. Her breasts are prominent and her body may extend to the right in a horizontal position (though this is unclear). She bends both arms upward and touches her face with her hands; both index fingers are bent. Her eyes are either closed or empty sockets.

Just right of the point at which the river(?) rises into a column, four figures swim or float in a horizontal line against the lower edge of the design. The leftmost figure is a nude, muscular male(?) in a contorted position who faces forward and looks down to the right, perhaps toward his female companion whose arm he appears to reach for or perhaps touch with his extended left arm. His right arm is raised horizontally at left with palm facing up. His hair appears to be short with a few longer tendrils at right; his head is tilted down and right. His right leg is bent beneath him, as his body is horizontal, and his left is bent backward.

Above the previous group of four figures, two figures, positioned just below and left of the bank, float or swim in the river(?) with bodies horizontal and heads at left. The figure at right is female, as indicated by her long hair and prominent breasts. She wears a gown or drapery and bends both legs sharply beneath her. Her left arm is at her side; her right is also by her side but bent behind her right hip. Her body faces up and forward but her head rests at an angle on her right shoulder. Her eyes are closed, perhaps suggesting she is dead.

Above the previous group of four figures, two figures, positioned just below and left of the bank, float or swim in the river(?) with bodies horizontal and heads at left. The figure at left is a nude, muscular male with short, curly hair who may have dark skin. His mouth is open and both of his arms are at his sides. He may touch his companion at right or, alternatively, the lower part of his body may be beneath hers.

Six pairs of figures occupy the first rightward bend in the whirlwind of water(?) from the point at which it rises upward to just before the apex of the first spiral. The lowest of these couples fly or hover just above the outstretched right arm of the single male figure lower left. A female figure with short hair wearing a gown faces forward with arms at her side but bent upward, palms facing forward. She turns left to look toward a second figure behind her, whom she may kiss. Both of her legs are bent with the right extended behind the left.

Six pairs of figures occupy the first rightward bend in the whirlwind of water(?) from the point at which it rises upward to just before the apex of the first spiral. The lowest of these couples fly or hover just above the outstretched right arm of the single male figure lower left. Only the head of the second figure is visible above and left of the female figure. This figure has short hair and downcast eyes to look toward the female figure below, whom he or she may kiss.

Six pairs of figures occupy the first rightward bend in the whirlwind of water(?) from the point at which it rises upward to just before the apex of the first spiral. To the right of the first couple, the second pair of figures fly or hover close to the right edge of the whirlwind. The female figure at right faces left but turns to look away from her companion forward and right. She has long hair and wears a gown. Her left arm is bent upward with her hand raised, palm facing away. With her right hand, she touches or holds the right arm of her companion. Her left leg is bent and extended slightly backward.

Six pairs of figures occupy the first rightward bend in the whirlwind of water(?) from the point at which it rises upward to just before the apex of the first spiral. To the right of the first couple, the second pair of figures fly or hover close to the right edge of the whirlwind. Left of the female figure who faces forward, a male figure faces away but turns right to look toward his companion, whom he appears to touch or hold with his bent right arm. He has short, curly hair and wears breeches (though he is nude from the waist up). His left arm is raised vertically and he points upward with his left index finger. Both legs appear to be extended backward and slightly bent, though the left is more prominent.

Six pairs of figures occupy the first rightward bend in the whirlwind of water(?) from the point at which it rises upward to just before the apex of the first spiral. Just above the head of the male figure in the second pair at right, two lightly drawn heads are visible facing left. The lower head may have long hair and so perhaps female. Her head is turned slightly up.

Six pairs of figures occupy the first rightward bend in the whirlwind of water(?) from the point at which it rises upward to just before the apex of the first spiral. Just above the head of the male figure in the second pair at right, two lightly drawn heads are visible facing left. The higher head has short hair and so perhaps male. His head is turned up with raised eyes; his mouth may be open.

Six pairs of figures occupy the first rightward bend in the whirlwind of water(?) from the point at which it rises upward to just before the apex of the first spiral. To the immediate left of the pair of detached heads, a large gowned female figure flies or hovers facing forward while a male figure, seen from behind, rises beside her at left. Her mouth may be open. She has long hair that she appears to pull upward with her left hand, which is bent and raised vertically. She touches together her left thumb and index finger. Her right arm is extended horizontally, though not visible as it is wrapped around the torso of her companion at left; her right hand holds his left side. She leans or bends prominently to the right. Her right leg is extended straight downward.

Six pairs of figures occupy the first rightward bend in the whirlwind of water(?) from the point at which it rises upward to just before the apex of the first spiral. To the immediate left of the pair of detached heads, a large gowned female figure flies or hovers facing forward while a male figure, seen from behind, rises beside her at left. The male figure flies or hovers facing away, leans to the right, and raises his right arm vertically. His hair is short and he appears to be nude above the waist; he also wears breeches. The female figure at his right wraps her right arm around his torso. Both legs are bent with the right extended backward.

Six pairs of figures occupy the first rightward bend in the whirlwind of water(?) from the point at which it rises upward to just before the apex of the first spiral. Directly above the first couple and left of the fourth couple, two figures fly or hover against the left side of the whirlwind to form the fifth couple. The female figure at left faces left but turns her head to look right. She has short hair and wears a gown; her mouth may be open. Her left arm is bent in front of her torso at 90 degrees, just above her companion's arm, which echoes the same position. Her left leg is extended downward with left foot pointed.

Six pairs of figures occupy the first rightward bend in the whirlwind of water(?) from the point at which it rises upward to just before the apex of the first spiral. Directly above the first couple and left of the fourth couple, two figures fly or hover against the left side of the whirlwind to form the fifth couple. The male figure at right has short hair and may be nude. He turns his head sharply up. His left arm is wrapped around the body of his female companion and at least one leg is extended downward.

Six pairs of figures occupy the first rightward bend in the whirlwind of water(?) from the point at which it rises upward to just before the apex of the first spiral. The sixth couple flies or hovers in an embrace above the fifth pair near the left edge of the whirlwind. The male figure at left appears to rise, facing left, but turn his head down to kiss his companion below him who wraps her arms around his head. His eyes may be closed. His hair is short and curly; he appears to be nude. Both arms are raised horizontally with palms facing down. One leg is extended behind him at left.

Six pairs of figures occupy the first rightward bend in the whirlwind of water(?) from the point at which it rises upward to just before the apex of the first spiral. The sixth couple flies or hovers in an embrace above the fifth pair near the left edge of the whirlwind. The female figure is seen from behind and faces away but turns her head up to kiss her male companion. She is nude with prominent buttocks and has short hair. Her eyes may be closed. Bending both arms upward, she twists left to wrap her arms around the head of the male figure in an embrace. Her legs are bent and extended behind her at left.

Eleven figures, many of whom are upside down or have bodies positioned horizontally, fly or hover in the single loop of the whirlwind of water(?) in the space between the apex of the loop and the point at which it doubles under itself. The leftmost of these figures flies near the bottom edge of the loop's apex. His body is horizontal facing down with head at right, though his head is turned to face up. He has short, curly hair and appears to wear breeches, though nude above the waist. His right arm is raised vertically, and he may hold or touch the female figure above him. His right leg is bent backward at a sharp angle, and his left is extended downward.

Eleven figures, many of whom are upside down or have bodies positioned horizontally, fly or hover in the single loop of the whirlwind of water(?) in the space between the apex of the loop and the point at which it doubles under itself. Just above the leftmost figure at the top of the loop, a female figure whose body is horizontal with her head at right faces forward and bends down at right. She has long hair and wears a gown; her abdomen and breasts are prominent. Her arms are raised vertically and clasped together above her head. She may be supported by the male figure below who appears to touch or hold her. Her legs are together and extended to the left, perhaps with the right crossed under the left.

Eleven figures, many of whom are upside down or have bodies positioned horizontally, fly or hover in the single loop of the whirlwind of water(?) in the space between the apex of the loop and the point at which it doubles under itself. To the immediate right of the leftmost female figure, a pair of figures who are seen from behind are upside down against the right edge of top loop of the whirlwind. The figure at left appears to be a partially nude male (he may wear breeches though his buttocks are exposed?). He may wear a ribbon or belt(?) around his waist. He has short hair and bends his head back to look down, perhaps toward the figure directly below him. His mouth may be open. Both arms are raised vertically, and he appears to touch the figure below him with his left hand and reach for this figure with his right hand. His left leg is extended backward and bent; his right is bent sharply with his foot raised near his buttocks.

Eleven figures, many of whom are upside down or have bodies positioned horizontally, fly or hover in the single loop of the whirlwind of water(?) in the space between the apex of the loop and the point at which it doubles under itself. To the immediate right of the leftmost female figure, a pair of figures who are seen from behind are upside down against the right edge of top loop of the whirlwind. The figure at right is a gowned female who bends her head back sharply. She has long hair, closed eyes, and an open mouth. Her left arm is raised vertically and she may touch or hold the leg of the figure below her. Her right arm is raised vertically but bent back so that her right hand is near (and perhaps touching) her face. Her legs are extended backward at left.

Eleven figures, many of whom are upside down or have bodies positioned horizontally, fly or hover in the single loop of the whirlwind of water(?) in the space between the apex of the loop and the point at which it doubles under itself. Directly below the female figure near the right side of the whirlwind, a male figure falls upside-down into the bank below. He is facing away and thus seen from behind. It is unclear whether he is nude or wearing a shirt and breeches(?). Both arms are raised at 135 degrees and on the ground. His legs are extended above him with knees bent.

Eleven figures, many of whom are upside down or have bodies positioned horizontally, fly or hover in the single loop of the whirlwind of water(?) in the space between the apex of the loop and the point at which it doubles under itself. To the left of the male figure falling into the bank, a female figure who is also upside down but facing forward, bends to the left. She may be falling. She has long hair and wears a gown. Turning her head to the right, the figure appears to look toward her companion at right with an open mouth. Both of her arms are raised vertically. Her legs are together and extended above her; the male figure above her touches her right leg.

Eleven figures, many of whom are upside down or have bodies positioned horizontally, fly or hover in the single loop of the whirlwind of water(?) in the space between the apex of the loop and the point at which it doubles under itself. Directly below the upside-down female figure near the bottom of the whirlwind's loop, a single male figure, visible only from the shoulders up, appears left of the bank. The short-haired head is positioned upside-down, bent slightly to the left.

Eleven figures, many of whom are upside down or have bodies positioned horizontally, fly or hover in the single loop of the whirlwind of water(?) in the space between the apex of the loop and the point at which it doubles under itself. The most prominent figure in the lower bend of the loop, a female figure faces forward with her body horizontal, head at left, and legs extended and together at right. She has long hair and wears a crown and a gown, though her breasts appear to be exposed. She turns to head to the right while bending her torso to the right as well. Her right arm is raised vertically and bent over her head; her left is extended horizontally, palm facing down.

Eleven figures, many of whom are upside down or have bodies positioned horizontally, fly or hover in the single loop of the whirlwind of water(?) in the space between the apex of the loop and the point at which it doubles under itself. Below the most prominent female figure in the lower bend of the loop, a male figure is visible, though partially obscured by the female figure's body. He is positioned horizontally, facing up, and his head is bent back. He has short hair and appears to be nude. His right arm is by his side and his right leg is extended up and right.

Eleven figures, many of whom are upside down or have bodies positioned horizontally, fly or hover in the single loop of the whirlwind of water(?) in the space between the apex of the loop and the point at which it doubles under itself. Two figures are visible just right of the point at which the whirlwind doubles under itself. The figure at left is a muscular male who faces away and appears to be nude. He may wear a belt(?) around his waist. He is seen from behind and bends to the right. His head is twisted sharply to the left, however, and slightly up, perhaps to look at the figures above him. His right arm appears to be extended away from his body, and his legs are together and extended backward with legs bent.

Eleven figures, many of whom are upside down or have bodies positioned horizontally, fly or hover in the single loop of the whirlwind of water(?) in the space between the apex of the loop and the point at which it doubles under itself. Two figures are visible just right of the point at which the whirlwind doubles under itself. The figure at right is only visible above the shoulders but faces forward and slightly left. He appears to be male and have short hair. His head is turned slightly up.

In the upper left corner, six pairs of figures fly upward or hover in the final section of the whirlwind of water(?) left of the large loop. The first pair occupies the lower left corner of the segment. The figure at left is female and seen from behind. Facing away, she turns her head to look right, perhaps at the male figure beside her at right. She has long hair and wears a gown. Her left arm is raised vertically or perhaps at 135 degrees in front of her. Her legs are together and extended backward and right; her left leg may be slightly bent. Her male companion at right touches her waist with both hands and appears to rest his head against her right shoulder.

In the upper left corner, six pairs of figures fly upward or hover in the final section of the whirlwind of water(?) left of the large loop. The first pair occupies the lower left corner of the segment. The male figure at right faces forward and turns his head up, likely to look toward his female companion at left, whose waist he holds with bent arms and spread fingers. His hair his short and he may be nude, though his lower body is not visible.

In the upper left corner, six pairs of figures fly upward or hover in the final section of the whirlwind of water(?) left of the large loop. To the right of the first two figures, the second pair of figures appears to emerge from beneath the loop of the whirlwind and are thus only partially visible. The female figure, who is lower, has long hair and may be nude or wear a gown or drapery. Seen from behind, she faces away but turns right to look up, perhaps at the figures above her, with her head up.

In the upper left corner, six pairs of figures fly upward or hover in the final section of the whirlwind of water(?) left of the large loop. To the right of the first two figures, the second pair of figures appear to emerge from beneath the loop of the whirlwind and are thus only partially visible. Above the female figure, the male figure faces forward and turns his head up to look up, possibly toward the figures above. His hair is short and perhaps curly and he may be nude. His arms may be by his sides, though his lower body is not represented.

In the upper left corner, six pairs of figures fly upward or hover in the final section of the whirlwind of water(?) left of the large loop. Visible in the center of this segment, the third pair is comprised of the largest figures. Slightly lower and facing away, the female(?) figure has long hair that extends from both sides of her head and wears a gown. She is seen from behind but twists her head to look right. Her mouth appears to be open. Both forearms are raised horizontally with arms then bent upward at ninety degrees. She touches or holds the right shoulder of her male companion with her left hand and may point upward with her right index finger. Her legs are extended with the left slightly bent.

In the upper left corner, six pairs of figures fly upward or hover in the final section of the whirlwind of water(?) left of the large loop. Visible in the center of this segment, the third pair is comprised of the largest figures. Slightly higher than the female figure, the male figure has somewhat long hair and may be nude. He faces left and his head is back, perhaps to look up at the figures above him. His mouth is open. His right arm appears to be by his side, and he may touch or reach for the female figure in front and below him.

In the upper left corner, six pairs of figures fly upward or hover in the final section of the whirlwind of water(?) left of the large loop. The fourth pair of figures is visible in the lower right corner of the segment. The female figure in this pair faces away and is seen from behind. She has long hair and wears a gown. Her left arm is raised and bent to hold the neck of her companion who flies slightly above her and places his right hand on her lower back or buttocks. Her legs are together and extended backward, perhaps slightly bent.

In the upper left corner, six pairs of figures fly upward or hover in the final section of the whirlwind of water(?) left of the large loop. The fourth pair of figures is visible in the lower right corner of the segment. The male figure faces left and turns his head up, perhaps to look toward the figures above him. His hair is short, and he may be nude or wear a gown(?). He extends his right arm, which is bent slightly, to touch the lower back of his female companion who embraces him.

In the upper left corner, six pairs of figures fly upward or hover in the final section of the whirlwind of water(?) left of the large loop. In the upper right corner of this segment, two figures face left with heads up and eyes closed. The gender of neither figure is apparent. The figure at right may have long hair and hold its right arm at its side.

In the upper left corner, six pairs of figures fly upward or hover in the final section of the whirlwind of water(?) left of the large loop. In the upper right corner of this segment, two figures face left with heads up and eyes closed. The gender of neither figure is apparent. Only the head of the figure at left is visible.

In the upper left corner, six pairs of figures fly upward or hover in the final section of the whirlwind of water(?) left of the large loop. Two figures embrace in the upper left corner of the segment. The lower figure appears to be female(?) and wear a gown. She faces away and is seen from behind. Her head is bent back and turned slightly to the right. Both arms are raised and the right is clearly bent around her male companion's neck in an embrace. Her legs are extended backward.

In the upper left corner, six pairs of figures fly upward or hover in the final section of the whirlwind of water(?) left of the large loop. Two figures embrace in the upper left corner of the segment. The higher figure appears to be male(?) with short hair. He faces forward but turns his head sharply to the left. His left arm may be by his side. The female figure in front of him holds him in an embrace around the neck.

lg.l: The Whirlwind of Lovers from Dantes Inferno canto VThe inscription is lightly scratched in drypoint in backwards writing that reads from right to left. This is almost certainly a preliminary notation, written right-way around on the copperplate and hence reversed in impressions from it, that would have been removed entirely, or engraved so that it prints right-way around, if Blake had completed the plate. Above this inscription, on a wave right of a human head, are fragmentary letters of the same, or very similar, inscription, also in reverse and mostly illegible.

desc.objtitle:
Ciampolo the Barrator Tormented by the Devils Ciampolo Tormented by the Devils, seiz'd on his arm and mangled bore away the sinewy part,
object 3 (Bentley 448.2)

objnote.p: The engraving is based on Blake's water color, Ciampolo the Barrator Tormented by the Devils, Butlin 812.41.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. Ciampolo, a corrupt former public servant, stands at the left side of the design. His right arm is bent forward at the elbow and he holds his right hand out with his palm forward and fingers spread. His left arm, slightly bent, is down and his palm is out. His fingers are bent and contorted. The hook that the devil to the right brandishes rips a loop of flesh from the bicep of Ciampolo's left arm. Ciampolo's head rests on his left shoulder. His mouth is open with teeth showing, and his eyes are swiveled to look in pain and horror at the wound to his arm. He has short, curly hair and is nude with visible genitals. At the right side of the design, several nude male demons perch together on a boulder. The body of the demon in the front faces right, but he twists his neck back and left to look torwards Ciampolo. His face, with his mouth open in a smile, is seen in three-quarters profile. He is nude and he has a beard and short, curly hair. His right leg is bent and drawn in towards the rock, while his bent left leg rests on the ground below. His right arm is raised at about 45 degrees and extended to the right, in front of him. He holds a staff, spear, or similar weapon with a hooked top in his right hand. His left arm appears to be by his side but bent upward; his left hand is by his chest with index finger pointing up and left. His bat-like wings are wrapped around his shoulders and arms. Behind him, the second demon, Libicocco, straddles the rock facing forward and extends his right leg down to the left. His right foot rests on the bank on tiptoe. His left leg is out to the right, bent with left heel propped against the rock. His head is tilted right but he looks forward with eyes directed to the right; he is smiling. He has long curly hair and bat-like wings spread wide on either side of his body. He reaches his right arm horizontally out to the left and uses a sharp hook to wound Ciampolo. His left hand appears to rest on his left knee. The head of a third demon is visible above the second demon's right arm, facing forward and to the left and tilted back to look up. His eyes are raised. This demon has short curly hair. His mouth is open and his wings are visible above his head. His right hand is visible just below Libicoco's right elbow, and he holds a similar spear or weapon with a hooked top. His straight right leg is also partially visible. The head and shoulders of a fourth demon are visible in the upper right corner. This demon faces forward and left. Tusks grow from his mouth, identifying him as Ciriatto. He has short curly hair and bat-like wings visible to the right of his head. He may hold a similar spear or weapon with a hook behind his left shoulder. The closest demon perches on a rock covered with indeterminate vegetation at the right side of the design. A similar rock is partly visible at the left side of the design. Both rocks sit on a bank or shore of the lake (perhaps of boiling pitch?), which appears between the rocks. Grass or vegetation appears in the lower right corner of the bank. Lines above the pitch suggest flames or steam rising from the surface of the lake. Dark and stormy clouds or smoke appear in the sky upper left.

component.illusobjdesc: Ciampolo, a corrupt former public servant, stands at the left side of the design. His legs are slightly bent; his lower body faces slightly right, but he twists at the waist and turns his upper body forward. His right arm is bent forward at the elbow and he holds his right hand out with his palm forward. His fingers are spread. His left arm, slightly bent, is down and his palm is out. His fingers are bent and contorted. The hook that the devil to the right brandishes rips a loop of flesh from the bicep of Ciampolo's arm. His head faces forward but is bent to the right, resting on his left shoulder. His mouth is open with his teeth showing, and his eyes are swiveled to look in pain and horror at the wound to his arm. He has short, curly hair and is nude with visible genitals.

At the right side of the design, several nude male demons sit or stand together near a boulder. The body of the demon in the front faces right, but he twists his neck back and left to look towards Ciampolo. His face, with his mouth open in a smile, is seen in three-quarters profile. He is nude and he has a beard and short, curly hair. His right leg is bent and drawn in towards the rock, while his bent left leg rests on the ground below. His right arm is raised at about 45 degrees and extended to the right, in front of him. He holds a staff, spear, hook, or similar weapon in his right hand. His left arm appears to be by his side but bent upward; his left hand is by his chest with index finger pointing up and left. His bat-like wings are wrapped around his shoulders and arms.

At the right side of the design, several nude male demons sit or stand together near a boulder. Second from front, the second demon, Libicocco, sits or stands straddling the rock facing forward and leaning to the right. He extends his right leg down to the left. His right foot rests on the bank on tiptoe. His left leg is out to the right, bent with left heel propped against the rock. His head is tilted right but he looks forward, mouth in a smile and eyes looking out to the right. He has long curly hair and bat-like wings spread wide on either side of his body. He reaches his right arm horizontally out to the left and uses a sharp hook to cut flesh from Ciampolo's left arm. His left arm may be at his side as he appears to grasp his left knee with his left hand.

At the right side of the design, several nude male demons sit or stand together near a boulder. The head of the third demon, farthest from front, is visible above the second demon's right arm, facing forward and to the left and tilted back to look up. His eyes are raised and his mouth is open in a smile. This demon has short, curly hair. His wings are visible above his head. His right hand is visible just below Libicocco's right elbow, and he holds a similar spear or weapon with a hooked top. His straight right leg is also partially visible, suggesting he is standing.

The head and shoulders of a fourth demon are visible in the upper right corner. This demon faces forward and left. Tusks grow from his mouth, identifying him as Ciriatto. He has short, curly hair and bat-like wings visible to the right of his head. He may hold a similar spear or weapon with a hooked top behind his left shoulder.

Each of the four devils on the right side of the composition holds a spear-like weapon with a hooked top. The second demon from the front, Libicocco, extends his weapon, which appears to be shorter than the others, to the left to hook and pull a loop of flesh from Ciampolo's left bicep. The other demons' hold their weapons vertically.

This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. The four demons sit or stand near a boulder at the right side of the design. A similar rock is partly visible at left. Both rocks sit on a bank or shore of the lake (perhaps of boiling pitch?), which appears between the rocks. Small pebbles and perhaps sand appear just above the lower edge of the design on the left and just right of center.

The boulder at right appears to be covered with indeterminate vegetation (perhaps moss as well as leaves and flowers?), particularly near the top. Grass or vegetation appears in the lower right corner of the bank.
Lines above the pitch suggest flames or steam rising from the surface of the lake. Dark and stormy clouds or smoke appear in the sky upper left.

desc.objtitle:
The Baffled Devils Fighting The Devils Fighting, so turn'd his talons on his comrade,
object 4 (Bentley 448.3)

objnote.p: The engraving is based on Blake's water color, The Baffled Devils Fighting, Butlin 812.42.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. The lake of boiling pitch stretches across the lower border of the design. Its liquid roils in whirls or waves. Flames lick up from its surface, particularly in the troughs of waves. Two devils attack one another in the air over the lake. Nude and muscular, they use the sharp claws on their hands to assail each other. The devil on the left flies or hovers with his body in a horizontal position. His torso faces down, though he bends backwards or lifts his shoulders and tilts his head back to look to the right. He twists at the waist so that his hips and legs face away towards the far shore of the lake, and are seen from behind. His left leg, slightly bent, extends to the left while his right leg is bent at the knee. The soles of both feet are visible. His bent arms are spread wide, with the right down and the left up. With the right palm down and left palm vertical and out, he spreads his fingers like talons. His jagged, bat-like wings rise up to the left from behind his shoulders. He has short, curly hair and his mouth is open. On the right, the opposing devil flies or hovers with his lower body extended to the right, facing forward. His right leg is bent and his genitals are visible. He twists at the waist; his torso faces down but he bends backwards or lifts his shoulders to look forward. His head is turned slightly left. He raises his right arm vertically and bends it right, over his head. His left arm is raised horizontally and bent up at the elbow, palm up and out towards the viewer. Like his opponent, his mouth is open and his teeth are visible. He has short, curly hair that stands on end. His bat-like wings extend from his back. Gentle hills form the far right bank of the lake. Groups of demons sit on several of these mounds at the right. Sitting and standing, they seem to have gathered to watch the pair of demons fight over the water. The majority of the demons raise one or both arms vertically. A larger hill rises on the left, and craggy mountains appear in the distance on the right. A path rises up from the lower left and circles around the larger hill. Two figures representing Dante and Virgil stand on the path near the top center of the design. In this instance, it is impossible to identity either figure specifically. They seem to face forward and to wear long gowns. The figure at left appears to look up. Flames rise from what appears to be a smaller pool of pitch in the bank at the left edge of the design. Larger and more threatening tongues of fire burn above the mountains on the right, at the horizon. The strip of sky visible along the upper margin of the design becomes dark at left, perhaps with clouds of smoke. Swirling lines in the sky above the mountains at right may suggest clouds or smoke.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. The lake of boiling pitch stretches across the lower border of the design. Its liquid roils in whirls or waves. Flames lick up from its surface, particularly in the troughs of waves.

Two devils attack one another in the air over the lake. Nude and muscular, they use the sharp claws on their hands to assail each other. The devil on the left flies or hovers with his body in a horizontal position. His torso faces down, though he bends backwards or lifts his shoulders and tilts his head back to look to the right. He twists at the waist so that his buttocks, hips, and legs face away towards the far shore of the lake, and are seen from behind. His left leg, slightly bent, extends to the left while his right leg is bent at the knee. The soles of both feet are visible. His bent arms are spread wide, with the right down and the left up. With right palm down and left palm vertical and out, he spreads his fingers like talons. His jagged, bat-like wings rise up to the left from behind his shoulders. He has short, curly hair and his mouth is open. His expression may suggest anger.

Two devils attack one another in the air over the lake. Nude and muscular, they use the sharp claws on their hands to assail each other. The devil on the right flies or hovers with his lower body extended to the right, facing forward. His right leg is bent and his genitals are visible. He twists at the waist; his torso faces down but he bends backwards or lifts his shoulders to look forward. His head is turned slightly left. He raises his right arm vertically and bends it right, over his head. His left arm is raised horizontally and bent up at the elbow, palm up and out towards the viewer. Like his opponent, his mouth is open and his teeth are visible. His expression suggests anger mixed with fear. He has short, curly hair that stands on end. His bat-like wings extend from his back.

Gentle hills form the far right bank of the lake. Groups of demons sit on several of these mounds. A larger hill rises on the left; a path rises up from the lower left and circles around this larger hill.
Craggy mountains appear in the distance on the right.

Flames rise from what appears to be a smaller pool or tiny lake of pitch in the bank at the left edge of the design. Larger and more threatening tongues of fire burn above the mountains on the right, at the horizon.
The strip of sky along the upper margin of the design becomes dark at left, perhaps with clouds of smoke. Swirling lines in the sky above the mountains at right may suggest smoke or clouds.

Two figures representing Dante and Virgil stand on the path near the top of the design. In this instance, it is impossible to identity either figure specifically. Both appear to face forward and wear long gowns. The figure at right may cross his bent arms in front of his chest. The figure at left may hold both arms at his sides with palms facing down.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. They all seem to be nude. Two of these demons stand together near the middle of the grouping, facing forward. The demon on the right stands with his right leg bent, foot partially raised on tiptoe. His genitals are faintly visible. His right arm is raised vertically with palm up and out. His left arm is down by his side and he may hold a pole or staff, visible right of his left leg, in his left hand. His head is turned slightly left and he has short hair; his mouth may be open. He also has bat-like wings.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. They all seem to be nude. Two of these demons stand together near the middle of the groupings, facing forward. The standing demon to the left raises his right hand with palm up and out. He has spiky, bat-like wings and short, curly hair. Like his companion at right, he too bends his head slightly left.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. Two of these demons stand together near the middle of the groupings, facing forward. On the same hill to the left, two demons sit next to each other. The seated demon on the right faces forward but turns his head slightly left, his mouth open. He has short, curly hair and his crossed legs appear to dangle over the edge of the hill. Both arms are bent and raised vertically. His left hand is raised, palm facing forward and left, while in his right he holds a long pole(?) that may be a weapon. Indistinct lines above and behind this figure may indicate bat-like wings, those these are less distinct than the wings of his companions.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. Two of these demons stand together near the middle of the groupings, facing forward. On the same hill to the left, two demons sit next to each other. The seated demon on the left faces forward and left with legs spread and genitals visible. His bent right leg rests diagonally along the hill; his bent left leg hangs down. This demon has short hair and may turn his head to look left. His left arm appears to be at his side, perhaps braced on the ground beside him, and his right is bent upward. In his right hand, he holds a long pole or weapon with a curved top, perhaps a hook. His bat-like wings appear over his right shoulder.

Three of the demons fathered on the far shore of the lake, at right, hold long poles or staffs. The second demon from the right holds his pole by his left leg whereas the fourth and fifth demons from the right hold their poles or staffs aloft in their right hands. Only the pole of the leftmost demon in this group has a curved, perhaps hooked top.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. The grouping farthest left includes three demons that sit together on a far hill. The leftmost of these three faces forward with legs extended left along the hill; his left leg may be bent. His right arm is raised at 135 degrees with palm up. Other features of this sketched figure, including gender, are difficult to discern, but he is probably male.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. The grouping farthest left includes three demons that sit together on a far hill. The middle demon in this group faces forward, with bent right leg lying to the left and bent left leg forward. This figure's right arm is raised at 135 degrees with palm up. Its left arm may be bent and down, perhaps resting on his left knee. Other features of this sketched figure, including gender, are difficult to discern, but he is probably male.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. The grouping farthest left includes three demons that sit together on a far hill. The rightmost demon of this group sits facing forward. He may lift his left arm at 135 degrees, palm facing up; alternatively, the lines above his head at right could suggest bat-like wings. He appears to sit with his left leg bent on the ground in front of him. Other features of this sketched figure, including gender, are difficult to discern, but he is probably male.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. Near the middle of this grouping, two of these demons stand together, facing forward. To the right of the standing demons, another demon sits facing forward with bent legs spread and head turned to the left. This demon is nude and seems to have female breasts and perhaps also long hair. Her right arm is raised at 135 degrees and bent upward at the elbow with palm forward. Her left arm is bent up at the elbow and may be propped on her left thigh.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. Two circular forms that may vaguely resemble heads are visible above the seated female demon at right.

desc.objtitle:
The Six-Footed Serpent Attacking Agnolo Brunelleschi The Six-Footed Serpent Attacks Agnello Brunelleschi, lo! a serpent with six feet springs forth on one,
object 5 (Bentley 448.4)

objnote.p: The engraving is based on Blake's water color, The Six-Footed Serpent Attacking Agnolo Brunelleschi, Butlin 812.51. A pencil drawing of the design in the Huntington Library (Butlin 822) is probably the direct preliminary for the engraving; it may have been transferred, face down, on to the copperplate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be bare earth or perhaps a lake(?). A mountain range with two low peaks crosses the design in the distance. A smaller, lower mound or hill appears in front of the mountain at right. Fire burns in the sky between the two mountains and may extend to the left margin. Dark forms above the right mountain suggest clouds or smoke in the sky. Five human figures and several other creatures occupy a stretch of earth in the foreground. Cianfa Donati, in the form of a many-limbed serpent, assaults Agnolo Brunelleschi, a nude and rather muscular male thief who stands at the center of the design. Facing forward, Brunelleschi stands in a slightly crouching posture with his bent right leg forward and his bent left leg back and extended slightly. His head is bent sharply left by the serpent, which bites his jaw, and his mouth and eyes are wide with horror and pain. His slightly bent right arm is extended at 45 degrees and drawn back. His right hand is open, with fingers spread and palm out. His left arm is at his side, bent up at the elbow with the palm of this hand facing the viewer and the fingers spread. The giant serpent attacking Brunelleschi bends or hunches forward over the man's back and clutches him with all six clawed feet, its limbs bent around his body. It lowers its head over the man's left shoulder to seize his jaw in its own open mouth. Its long, snake-like tail emerges from between Brunelleschi's legs and coils twice around his right leg before trailing onto the ground. The monster's large, bat-like wings appear above its shoulders. A small rocky outcropping rises in the lower left corner of the design. It may be covered with indistinct vegetation, perhaps grass. Dante and Virgil, who both wear gowns and have long hair, stand together on a ledge in this outcropping. Dante stands to the left, facing forward and partly hiding Virgil. His straight arms are down by his side; his hands are open with palms down. The fingers of his left hand appear to be spread. He bends his head to the right, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile. His mouth is slightly open. Virgil, slightly to the right of Dante, stands facing forward and to the right. His head is lowered and he holds his forearms across his torso. Two male figures stand together at the right side of the design. Nude, they represent the spirits of Puccio Sciancato and Buoso Donati, Brunelleschi's fellow robbers. Their individual identities are not distinguished. The rightmost figure hides his companion slightly and faces away. He stands in a contrapposto position, bending left at the waist with most of his weight on his right leg; his left leg is bent backwards, with his left foot on tiptoe. He turns his head left and bends it down, so that his face is seen in profile looking down to the left. His mouth is open. His right forearm, bent upward, is visible at the right of his torso. His right hand as well as his left hand, which appears above his right shoulder, are open with palms facing forward and fingers spread. The figure on the left faces forward in a slightly contrapposto position, with his weight shifted to his left leg and his right leg bent backwards. He bends and twists slightly to the left and turns his head left, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile. His mouth is open and his genitals are visible. Both of his forearms are raised horizontally, with his hands open, fingers spread, and palms out. Snakes abound on the ground below the figures and in the floor of the trench. One appears to the right of Brunelleschi's feet, its body forming two incomplete loops and its head raised to look forward. The heads of two snakes are visible to the right of the rocky outcropping in the lower left corner of the design. Side-by-side, both look up; they may be watching the six-footed serpent attack Brunelleschi. Between Brunelleschi and Virgil, a snake may appear in the distance on the floor of the trench. Its body coils into three raised loops but appears more abstracted than the other snakes. To the right of Brunelleschi's left hip, another serpent is visible in the distance undulating along the floor of the trench or with its tail extended over the body of water or bare earth. Its head seems to be raised; it looks up. Just below the mountain on the right, a snake's body curves up from the floor of the trench or on the far side of the lake or bare earth. The head of another serpent is raised just to the left of the right edge of the design, perhaps as if rising out of the lake. It looks forward and to the left with its mouth open. The head and part of the body of a snake appears in the lower right corner of the design. The reptile's head is raised and looks left with its mouth open, displaying fangs and an extended tongue. Small clusters of spiky tufts, perhaps of grass or fire, appear throughout the design; these are particularly noticeable just above the lower margin.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be bare earth or perhaps a lake(?).
A mountain range with two low peaks crosses the design in the distance. A smaller, lower mound or hill appears in front of the mountain at right.
Fire burns in the sky between the two mountains and may extend to the left margin.
Dark forms above the right mountain suggest clouds or smoke in the sky.

A many-limbed serpent assaults Agnolo Brunelleschi, a nude and rather muscular male thief who stands at the center of the design. Facing forward, Brunelleschi stands in a slightly crouching posture with his bent right leg forward and his bent left leg back slightly. Both feet seem to be on tiptoe. His head is bent sharply left by the serpent, which bites his jaw, and his mouth and eyes are wide with horror and pain. His open mouth displays his teeth and tongue. His right cheek may touch his right shoulder. His eyes are swiveled to the right towards the head of the serpent, and his short hair stands up. His slightly bent right arm is extended at 45 degrees and drawn back. His right hand is open, with fingers spread and palm out. His left arm is at his side, bent up at the elbow with the palm of this hand facing the viewer and the fingers spread.

Cianfa Donati, in the form of a scaly limbed serpent, somewhat lizard-like, assaults Agnolo Brunelleschi, a nude and rather muscular male thief who stands at the center of the design. The giant creature bends or hunches forward over the man's back and clutches him with all six clawed feet, its limbs bent around his body. It lowers its head over the man's left shoulder and seizes his jaw in its own open mouth, bending his head sharply left. A hornlike protuberance (or a small tuft of short hair) grows from its head. Its long, snake-like tail emerges from between Brunelleschi's legs and coils twice around his right leg before trailing onto the ground. The monster's large, bat-like wings appear above its shoulders.

Five human figures and several other creatures occupy a stretch of earth in the foreground. A small rocky outcropping rises in the lower left corner of the design. It may be covered with indistinct vegetation, perhaps grass.

Dante and Virgil stand together on a small ledge in the rocky outcropping at the left side of the design. Dante stands to the left, facing forward and partly hiding Virgil. He wears a long gown, but the shape of his shoulders and hips beneath it suggests that he stands in contrapposto, leaning slightly right. His straight arms are down by his side; his hands are open with palms down. The fingers of his left hand appear to be spread. He bends his head to the right, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile. He has long curly hair and his mouth is slightly open.

Dante and Virgil stand together on a small ledge in the rocky outcropping at the left side of the design. Virgil stands slightly to the right of Dante, facing forward and to the right; he may look toward the monster attacking the thief at right. His head is lowered, and he bends his arms upward to hold his forearms across his torso. He grasps his right wrist with his left hand; his right hand rests on his shoulder. He wears a long gown and has long hair. His right foot is visible beneath his gown.

Two male figures stand together at the right side of the design. Both are nude. They represent the spirits of Puccio Sciancato and Buoso Donati, Brunelleschi's fellow robbers. Their individual identities are not distinguished. The rightmost figure hides his companion slightly and faces away. He stands in a contrapposto position, bending left at the waist with most of his weight on his right leg; his left leg is bent and extended backwards, with his left foot on tiptoe. He turns his head left and bends it down, so that his face is seen in profile looking down to the left. His mouth is open and his short hair stands on end, suggesting fear or terror. His right forearm, bent upward, is visible at the right of his torso. Both palms are open (the right facing away from the viewer and the left facing forward) and fingers spread.

Two male figures stand together at the right side of the design. Both are nude. They represent the spirits of Puccio Sciancato and Buoso Donati, Brunelleschi's fellow robbers. Their individual identities are not distinguished. The figure on the left faces forward in a slightly contrapposto position, with his weight shifted to his left leg and his right leg bent. He bends slightly to the left and turns his head left, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile. Both of his forearms are raised horizontally, with his hands open, fingers spread, and palms out. His long curly hair falls over his shoulders. His mouth is open in what may be an expression of fear or terror and his genitals are pictured.

Snakes abound on the ground below the figures and in the floor of the trench or lake. One appears to the right of Brunelleschi's feet, its body forming two incomplete loops and its head raised to look forward. It has several spiky scales behind its head and on its back, and a small whisker(?) on either side of its snout.

The heads of two snakes are visible to the right of the rocky outcropping in the lower left corner of the design. Side-by-side, both look up; they may be watching the six-footed serpent attack Brunelleschi.

Between Brunelleschi and Virgil, a snake may appear in the distance on the floor of the trench. Its body coils into three raised loops but appears more abstracted than the other snakes. Its head is not visible.

To the right of Brunelleschi's left hip, another serpent is visible in the distance undulating along the floor of the trench or with its tail extended over the body of water or bare earth. Its head seems to be raised; it looks up.
Just below the mountain on the right, a snake's body curves up from the floor of the trench or on the far side of the lake or bare earth. Its head is not visible.

The head of a serpent is raised just to the left of the right edge of the design, perhaps as if rising out of the lake or bare earth. It looks forward and to the left with its mouth open and may breathe fire.

The head and part of the body of a snake appears in the lower right corner of the design. The reptile's head is raised and looks left with its mouth open, displaying fangs and an extended tongue, and perhaps breathing fire. The serpent has short legs that face right.
Small clusters of spiky tufts, perhaps of grass or fire, appear throughout the design; these are particularly noticeable just above the lower margin.

desc.objtitle:
The Serpent Attacking Buoso Donati The Serpent Attacks Buoso De' Donati, He ey'd the serpent and the serpent him,
object 6 (Bentley 448.5)

objnote.p: The engraving is based on Blake's water color The Serpent Attacking Buoso Donati, Butlin 812.53.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench in the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be flat earth. Tongues of fire leap from the floor of the trench nearly to the top of the design, forming a backdrop extending horizontally across the design. Clouds, possibly of smoke, also cross the top of the design. More flames burst downward from the clouds in the upper left corner, center, and far right margin. Four figures and a snake occupy a strip of earth in the foreground separate from the trench. Small flames burning in a line span the plate horizontally and appear to separate the earth in the foreground from the background floor of the trench. The flames extend as far right as Donati's right leg. This figure, Buoso Donati, stands at the right side of the design; he has just been bitten by a snake. He is nude and his navel displays the wound from the serpent's bite. He bends to the left at the waist and lowers his head to look down at the serpent below and to the left. His mouth is open in a yawn, as Dante's text describes, displaying his teeth and tongue. Alternatively, he may be crying out in pain. His expression suggests surprised confusion as well as pain and terror. The short hair around his head stands on end; longer locks fall past his shoulders. Both of his arms are down, but bent upward at the elbow. His right arm crosses his torso with his open right hand raised, vertical palm facing away and fingers spread. His left arm is raised to the right with the palm of this hand facing out and up to the right and the fingers spread. His right leg is bent and his heel may be lifted off the ground. The snake that has just bitten Buoso Donati appears below him to the left. It seems to be suspended in the air in the process of falling back to earth. Both the wound and the serpent emit smoke, together forming a cloud that links the snake's mouth with the injury it created. The scaly serpent has thin arms with long talen-like fingers; two sets of protrusions on its lower body resemble fins(?). Dante and Virgil, who are both gowned, stand together at the left edge of the design, on a slightly raised stone mound in the lower left corner. Dante stands slightly to the left of Virgil, facing forward. He bends to the right and turns his head rightward so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His head is also bent down slightly. His arms are down by his side and bent at the elbows, so that his forearms are horizontal. His hands are raised, with vertical palms facing out towards the viewer. Virgil, to the right of and slightly hidden by Dante, faces forward and to the right. He bends his head and turns it right, so that his face is visible in profile. His left arm is bent at the elbow. The nude figure of Puccio Sciancato, one of Brunelleschi's fellow robbers, stands just to the right of Dante and Virgil. Sciancato stands in an awkward twisted posture: his left leg is positioned to face right but his right leg and hips face forward while his shoulders face slightly left. He turns his slightly bent head back to the right, so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile looking right. He also leans backward slightly, away from Buoso Donati. His right arm is extended down by his side and drawn back, with the palm of his open right hand facing down. His left arm is bent up at the elbow and drawn across his torso. His left hand makes a fist and may rest on his breastbone. His right leg is forward, while his left leg is drawn back. His facial expression and his body language together suggest fear. A snake is crawling across the ground behind Sciancato. It faces left and moves with its mouth open.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench in the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be flat earth.
Tongues of fire leap from the floor of the trench nearly to the top of the design, forming a backdrop extending horizontally across the design.
Clouds, possibly of smoke, cross the top of the design.
Flames burst downward from the clouds in the upper left corner, center, and far right margin.

Four figures and a snake occupy a strip of earth in the foreground separate from the trench. Small flames burning in a line span the plate horizontally and appear to separate the earth in the foreground from background floor of the trench. The flames extend as far right as Donati's right leg.

Buoso Donati stands at the right side of the design facing forward; he has just been bitten by a snake. He is nude and his navel displays the wound from the serpent's bite. He stands with his left leg straight and his right leg bent, with his right foot on tiptoe. He bends to the left at the waist and lowers his head to look down at the serpent below and to the left. His mouth is open in a yawn, as Dante's text describes, displaying his teeth and tongue. Alternatively, he may be crying out in pain. His expression suggests surprised confusion as well as pain, fear, and terror. The short hair around his head stands on end; longer locks fall past his shoulders. Both of his arms are down, but bent upward at the elbow. His right arm crosses his torso with his open right hand raised, vertical palm facing away and fingers spread. His left arm is raised to the right with the palm of this hand facing out and up to the right and the fingers spread. He appears to twist his torso right slightly, away from the snake. His genitals, possibly with scales reaching up his lower stomach, are pictured.

The snake that has just bitten Buoso Donati appears below him to the left. It seems to be suspended in the air in the process of falling back to earth. The end of its tail may rest along Donati's right thigh; the rest of its body curls around to form an incomplete loop so that its head faces back up to the right towards Donati's face. Small spiky scales cover its body and a spiky crest appears on its head. Its mouth is open slightly and smoke emerges. The creature has thin arms with long talon-like fingers extended below its head. Two sets of protrusions on its lower body resemble fins(?).
Both the wound and the serpent emit smoke, together forming a cloud that links the snake's mouth with the injury it created.

Dante and Virgil stand together at the left edge of the design. Dante stands to the left of Virgil, facing forward. He bends to the right and turns his head rightward so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His head is also bent down slightly. His arms are down by his side and bent at the elbows, so that his forearms are horizontal. His hands are raised, with vertical palms facing out towards the viewer. He has long curly hair and wears a long gown that pools on the ground beneath him.

Dante and Virgil stand together at the left edge of the design. Virgil stands to the right of Dante, slightly hidden by him, and faces forward and to the right. He bends his head and turns it right, so that his face is visible in profile, head slightly down. He may look toward the snake below at right. His left arm is bent at the elbow. Virgil has long curly hair, and wears a long gown.
Dante and Virgil stand on a slightly raised stone mound in the lower left corner of the design.

The nude figure of Puccio Sciancato, one of Brunelleschi's fellow robbers, stands just to the right of Dante and Virgil. Sciancato stands in an awkward twisted posture: his left leg is positioned to face right but his right leg and hips face forward while his shoulders face slightly left. He turns his slightly bent head back to the right, so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile looking right. His eyes are raised. He also leans backward slightly, away from Buoso Donati. His right arm is extended down by his side and drawn back, with the palm of his open right hand facing down. His left arm is bent up at the elbow and drawn across his torso. His left hand makes a fist and may rest on his breastbone. His right leg is forward, while his left leg is drawn back; his genitals are visible. His facial expression and his body language together suggest fear. He has short curly hair, some of which stands on end.
A snake is crawling across the ground behind Sciancato. It faces left and moves with its mouth open.

desc.objtitle:
The Pit of Disease: The Falsifiers The Alchemists and Forgers, Then two I mark'd that sat propp'd 'gainst each other,
object 7 (Bentley 448.6)

objnote.p: The engraving is based on Blake's water color, The Pit of Disease: The Falsifiers, Butlin 812.58.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the tenth trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench stretches the length of the bottom of the design, and seems to be bare earth, furrowed in places or perhaps water in the center and/or far right. A rock bridge arches down from the upper right corner of the design to the floor of the trench. A second rock bridge arches from the upper left corner of the design down to the floor of the trench below, near the lower left corner. Nude human forms are visible in this bridge, petrified in contorted positions. Most of these forms are difficult to resolve into individuals. Two additional rock bridges in the distance are visible between the bridges that appear at either side of the design. Part of another distant rock bridge appears in the lower right corner of the design, to the right of the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. A dark cloud fills the top left corner of the design and extends most of the way across the top edge of the design. Tongues of flame lick down from beneath the cloud in the upper left corner. Undulating lines in the sky in the center, both above and below the middle rock bridges, and in the lower right corner, below the distant bridge, suggest smoke or cloud. Dante and Virgil stand side-by-side on a small shelf in the stone bridge at the right. Dante stands to the left of Virgil and obscures his companion slightly. Both wear long gowns, and bend their arms up at the elbow in front of their torsos, with hands together in front of their faces. Each may hold his nose. Four "falsifiers," or forgers, who are now afflicted with disease lie in a huddle in the lower left corner of the design, near the base of the human bridge. The leftmost of these lies supine with his(?) head at right and body partially resting against the sinner behind him, so that his torso faces forward as well as up. With the exception of his face, his head and body are completely draped. His eyes are closed. The figure on which the leftmost figure leans sits upright facing forward with head and eyes raised up, perhaps with tears in the corners of each eye. The figure has long hair and may be female. Her mouth may be open. The majority of her body is obscured by the third figure in the group who lies supine in front of her and on whom the second figure rests her folded arms and hands. The third figure turns his(?) head to face forward, and his mouth is open widely. His right arm is extended, raised at 135 degrees, palm facing down. He may be nude or wear drapery around his lower body. His legs may be bent upward, but they are partially blocked by the fourth and final figure in this group at right. This heavy sinner to the right lies or crawls with his belly resting on his right leg, which is bent and drawn up beneath him and lies on the ground. This sinner's bent left leg is extended to the right and his left foot rests on tiptoe. He bends backwards and lifts his torso, bending his head back to look left. His mouth is open. His left arm is down and his elbow, forearm, and many of the spread fingers of his left hand all rest on the ground. Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. Two males at the top of the pile sit with their backs together. They are Griffolino of Arezzo and Capocchio of Siena, both of whom were alchemists. The rightmost of these faces right and away, and bends to the right to look forward. His right arm is down and bent up at the elbow across his lower back; he raises his right hand and uses his spread fingers to scratch his back. His left arm is raised and bent down past his head, and he scratches his back between his shoulder blades with the fingers on this hand. The other seated male faces left.
