His left arm is by his side, bent up at the elbow across his back, which he scratches with the spread fingers of his left hand. He bends forward sharply over his own lap. Both figures appear to have nets over their bent legs The forms of the other sinners lumped into the pile are difficult to distinguish, though at least seven faces and several more heads and upper bodies emerge. They are forgers. Additional faces and figures appear throughout the landscape, including a bearded male figure with arm bent upward depicted within the base of the rightmost rock bridge, a vaguer face just above him, and four heads visible emerging from the trench floor or lake below the arch of the central rock bridges.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the tenth trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench stretches the length of the bottom of the design, and seems to be bare earth, furrowed in places or perhaps water in the center and/or at far right. Small flames appear in two short lines on the ground in the lower middle of the design.
A rock bridge arches down from the upper right corner of the design to the floor of the trench. It is partly dark with shadow.

A second rock bridge arches from the upper left corner of the design down to the floor of the trench below, near the lower left corner. The inside edge of the bridge is dark with shadow. Nude human forms are visible in the bridge, petrified in contorted positions.

In the second rock bridge that arches from the upper left corner of the design to the floor of the trench below in the lower left corner, there are many petrified bodies that appear to be dead, likely from disease. Some bodies are fully visible, others only partially. Just above the base of the arch, a gowned figure lies supine facing up, its body extending across the bridge horizontally. Its left arm is at its side and its head is bent back with eyes closed. Its long hair falls on the rock below.

In the second rock bridge that arches from the upper left corner of the design to the floor of the trench below in the lower left corner, there are many petrified bodies that appear to be dead, likely from disease. Some bodies are fully visible, others only partially. The second figure from the base of the arch lies supine with the top of her(?) head at left, facing up. Only her head and upper body are visible. She has long hair and her eyes appear to be open. Her head is bent back slightly.

In the second rock bridge that arches from the upper left corner of the design to the floor of the trench below in the lower left corner, there are many petrified bodies that appear to be dead, likely from disease. Some bodies are fully visible, others only partially. The lower body and right arm of the third figure from the base of the arch is visible, facing right. The figure's right arm is bent and resting on its lap, hand on knee. Its legs are bent, suggesting the figure is (or was) sitting. The head of the figure becomes indistinguishable at left.

In the second rock bridge that arches from the upper left corner of the design to the floor of the trench below in the lower left corner, there may be a net to the right of the third petrified figure's legs.

In the second rock bridge that arches from the upper left corner of the design to the floor of the trench below in the lower left corner, there are many petrified bodies that appear to be dead, likely from disease. Some bodies are fully visible, others only partially. Above the third figure from the bottom, at least two heads are visible near the right side of the rock formation. The lower head appears to have short hair and face down, and the higher head has long hair that falls down. This head too faces down, and the figure's left arm may dangle down as well.

In the second rock bridge that arches from the upper left corner of the design to the floor of the trench below in the lower left corner, there are many petrified bodies that appear to be dead, likely from disease. Some bodies are fully visible, others only partially. In the middle of the formation above the two heads, a figure lies supine facing up and slightly forward, its body extending horizontally across the rock bridge with head at right, eyes closed and long hair dangling down. Its head is turned left to rest on its shoulder. It may be gowned with left arm at its side.

In the second rock bridge that arches from the upper left corner of the design to the floor of the trench below in the lower left corner, there are many petrified bodies that appear to be dead, likely from disease. Some bodies are fully visible, others only partially. In the upper part of the rock bridge, the most clearly visible figure sits facing forward with head at left, resting on her(?) shoulder, and long hair dangling down. Her eyes are closed. Her arms are at her sides and her ribs are prominent. She may be nude or gowned. Her legs are bent upward and together, leaning slightly to the right.

In the second rock bridge that arches from the upper left corner of the design to the floor of the trench below in the lower left corner, there are many petrified bodies that appear to be dead, likely from disease. Some bodies are fully visible, others only partially. Just left of the feet of the sitting, forward-facing figure in the upper part of the rock bridge, the head and shoulders of a figure are visible at left. This figure lies supine with head turned right to face forward. Her hair may be long, suggesting she is female. Her eyes are closed and her mouth may be open.

In the second rock bridge that arches from the upper left corner of the design to the floor of the trench below in the lower left corner, there are many petrified bodies that appear to be dead, likely from disease. Some bodies are fully visible, others only partially. Just left of the right arm of the sitting, forward-facing figure in the upper part of the rock bridge, the head and knees of a foreshortened figure are visible. The figure lies supine facing up with the top of its head toward the viewer and legs bent at the knees. Only his upper legs are visible.

In the second rock bridge that arches from the upper left corner of the design to the floor of the trench below in the lower left corner, there are many petrified bodies that appear to be dead, likely from disease. Some bodies are fully visible, others only partially. In the uppermost left corner, a final body is vaguely visible: a contracted figure with a round head and bent knees appears to sit facing right and forward.
Two additional rock bridges in the distance are visible between the bridges that appear at either side of the design.
Part of a distant rock bridge appears in the lower right corner of the design, to the right of the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand.
A dark cloud fills the top left corner of the design and extends most of the way across the top edge of the design.
Tongues of flame lick down from beneath the cloud in the upper left corner.
Undulating lines in the sky in the center, both above and below the middle rock bridges, and in the lower right corner, below the distant bridge, suggest smoke or clouds.

Dante and Virgil stand side-by-side on a small shelf in the stone bridge at the right. Dante stands to the left of Virgil and obscures his companion slightly. He faces forward and slightly left. His long gown covers his arms and hands, but both arms seem to be bent up at the elbow in front of his torso, with hands together in front of his face. He may be holding his nose. He tilts his head forward, and his eyes are lowered or closed. He has long hair.

Dante and Virgil stand side-by-side on a small shelf in the stone bridge at the right. Virgil stands to the right of Dante, obscured slightly by his companion. He faces forward and slightly left. His long gown covers his arms and hands, but both arms seem to be bent up at the elbow in front of his torso, with hands together in front of his face. He may be holding his nose, and his eyes are lowered or closed. He has long hair.

Four "falsifiers" or forgers now afflicted with disease lie in a huddle in the lower left corner of the design, near the base of the bridge of human forms. The leftmost of these lies supine with his(?) head at right and body partially resting against the sinner at right, so that his torso faces forward as well as up. Except for his face, his head and body are completely draped. His eyes are closed.

Four "falsifiers" or forgers now afflicted with disease lie in a huddle in the lower left corner of the design, near the base of the bridge of human forms. The figure on which the leftmost figure leans sits upright facing forward with head and eyes raised up, perhaps with tears in the corners of each eye. The figure has long hair and may be female. Her mouth may be open. The majority of her lower body is obscured by the third figure in the group who lies supine in front of her and on whom the second figure rests her folded arms and hands. She may be nude.

Four "falsifiers" or forgers now afflicted with disease lie in a huddle in the lower left corner of the design, near the base of the bridge of human forms. The third figure in the group lies supine with head at left, turned to face forward with mouth open widely, perhaps in an expression of fear, terror, or pain. The figure appears to be male(?), and he may be nude or wear drapery around his lower body. His short hair may stand on end or simply fall behind him. His right arm is extended, raised at 135 degrees, palm facing down. His legs may be bent upward, but they are partially blocked by the fourth figure in this group at right. The female figure behind him rests her folded arms on the left side of his chest.

Four "falsifiers" or forgers now afflicted with disease lie in a huddle in the lower left corner of the design, near the base of the bridge of human forms. The rightmost of these is a heavy nude male who lies or crawls with his belly resting on his right leg, which is bent and drawn up beneath him and lies on the ground. The sinner's bent left leg is extended to the right and his left foot rests on tiptoe. He bends backwards and lifts his torso, bending his head back to look left. His mouth is open. His left arm is down and his elbow, forearm, and many of the spread fingers of his left hand all rest on the ground. He is balding, but his remaining hair is short and curly.

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. Two males at the top of the pile sit with their backs together. They represent Griffolino of Arezzo and Capocchio of Siena, who were alchemists. The figure at right faces right and away, so that viewers see him from behind. He bends to the right to look forward. His right leg seems to be bent at the knee, over the bodies of his fellow sinners. His right arm is down and bent up at the elbow across his lower back; he raises his right hand and uses his spread fingers to scratch his back. His left arm is raised and bent down past his head, perhaps resting on it. He scratches his back between his shoulder blades with the fingers on his left hand. His head is bent down and turned to the right and forward so that it is visible in three-quarters view. He has short, curly hair and appears to be nude except for a net(?) or patterned drapery visible below his waist.

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. Two males at the top of the pile sit with their backs together. They represent Griffolino of Arezzo and Capocchio of Siena, who were alchemists. The figure at left faces left and bends forwrd sharply over his own lap to look down with head down. He appears to be nude except for a net(?) or patterned drapery visible below his waist. His left leg seems to be bent at the knee. His left arm is by his side, bent up at the elbow across his back, which he scratches with the spread fingers of his left hand. He is nude and balding, and what is left of his hair is short and curly.
Nets or patterned drapery cover the laps and bent legs of the two seated figures, Griffolino of Arezzo and Capocchio of Siena, in the lower right corner.

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. The forms of most of the nude sinners, who represent forgers, are difficult to distinguish, though at least seven faces and several more heads are visible. At the right of the pile, the upper body of a male lies supine with head back and bearded chin tilted up so far his face looks right. He may have long hair. His eyes are closed, perhaps suggesting he is dead.

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. The forms of most of the nude sinners, who represent forgers, are difficult to distinguish, though at least seven faces and several more heads are visible. The second figure from the right is a male figure whose head and shoulders are visible. He appears to lie on his side facing forward but bends his head sharply up and to the right. His mouth is open in an expression of pain. He may be nude and have short hair.

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. The forms of most of the nude sinners, who represent forgers, are difficult to distinguish, though at least seven faces and several more heads are visible. The third figure from the right is a female figure whose upper body is visible. She lies supine with head, which is tilted slightly left, toward the viewer and long hair on the ground around her. Her eyes are closed, perhaps suggesting she is dead. Her breasts are prominent and she may be nude.

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. The forms of most of the nude sinners, who represent forgers, are difficult to distinguish, though at least seven faces and several more heads are visible. Only the heads of the fourth and sixth figures from the right are visible, facing down. These heads appear to have short curly hair.

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. The forms of most of the nude sinners, who represent forgers, are difficult to distinguish, though at least seven faces and several more heads are visible. The fifth figure from the right lies supine on top of other figures in the pile with head and shoulders visible and bent backward so that the figure faces forward. The figure's eyes are closed (perhaps suggesting death) and it may have long hair.

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. The forms of most of the nude sinners, who represent forgers, are difficult to distinguish, though at least seven faces and several more heads are visible. Directly below the left knee of the sitting figure at left, the head and upper body of the third figure in the pile from the left are visible. This figure lies supine but bends backward to face forward. His hair is short and his mouth is open (with teeth visible) in an expression of pain. He may be nude.

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. The forms of most of the nude sinners, who represent forgers, are difficult to distinguish, though at least seven faces and several more heads are visible. The second figure from the left in the pile lies supine facing up, head tilted right to face slightly forward. Only the head and shoulders of the figure are visible. The figure has long hair and an open mouth.

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. The forms of most of the nude sinners, who represent forgers, are difficult to distinguish, though at least seven faces and several more heads are visible. The leftmost figure, represented as more than just a head, in the pile is the only figure who partially sits up facing forward, his head and upper body visible. He has short, curly hair that may grow only in tufts, and he is nude. His head is bent back slightly. His right arm appears to be raised and crossed in front of his body, which may extend to the left (but is obscured by the figure in front of him).

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. The forms of most of the nude sinners, who represent forgers, are difficult to distinguish, though at least seven faces and several more heads are visible. To the left of the pile, there may be an additional head with long dark hair that faces down.

Additional faces and figures appear throughout the landscape. One of these is a bearded male figure with arm bent upward depicted within the base of the rightmost rock bridge. This figure faces right, appears to be sitting, and may wear a gown. He may hold a pen or writing instrument in his right hand and write, perhaps on a book or tablet. He appears to be petrifying into the rocks.

Additional faces and figures appear throughout the landscape. Just above the bearded male figure depicted in the base of the rightmost rock bridge, a vague face appears almost indistinguishable from the rock itself. Eyes, brows, and a nose are visible and appear to face forward.

Additional faces and figures appear throughout the landscape. Just below the ledge on which Dante and Virgil stand, a figure depicted in the rock sits facing forward with legs drawn up and body hunched forward, contracted. The figure has long hair that appears to cover its face. He or she may be petrifying into rock.
On the rock to the right of Dante and Virgil, a lizard may be visible facing right with its right eye toward the viewer. A crest on its head distinguishes the animal from the rock.

Additional faces and figures appear throughout the landscape. Four heads are visible emerging from the trench floor or lake below the arch of the central rock bridges. The rightmost of these faces forward whereas the other three heads are bent back and face up. These figures may be diseased or dead.

desc.objtitle:
Dante Striking Against Bocca Degli Abati Dante Strikes Against Bocca Degli Abbati, "Wherefore dost bruise me?" weeping he exclaim'd,
object 8 (Bentley 448.7)

objnote.p: The engraving is based on Blake's water color, Dante Striking Against Bocca Degli Abati, Butlin 812.65.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth circle of hell, on a frozen lake that stretches across the bottom of the design. The base of a rock bridge is visible at the right side of the design, rising from the surface of the frozen lake to the upper right corner of the design. Four petrified or frozen nude human forms appear in the bridge: a figure in the top right sits with eyes closed and knees bent upward, hands holding its head; the leftmost figure kneels or crouches facing forward and left with hands clasped together and tears streaming down his face; in the bottom middle of the bridge two upside-down nude figures lie with legs extended or bent upward and heads bent back into the lake below. Dark lines to the left of the rock bridge at the right edge of the design suggests a dark sky, perhaps with clouds, which grows lighter as it approaches the left edge of the design. A rock or low mound is visible at the left edge of the design, near the lower left corner. This may be stone or frozen ice. Shadow covers the surface of the lake in the distance to the right of this mound. In front of the mound at right, a human head appears on the surface of the ice. The head has long hair and closed eyes. It faces forward and leans to the left. Between this head and the mound, there is another round form that is less defined but may suggest a second head or mound. The two gowned figures of Dante and Virgil stand on the ice at the left side of the design. Dante stands at left, facing forward and slightly to the right. He tilts his head to the right and bends it down. His left arm is down by his side, and he holds his left hand very slightly forward, with his vertical palm facing out. His right arm is down and bent forward at the elbow; his open right hand is raised at a right angle with the vertical palm facing out. Virgil stands to the right of Dante, who hides him slightly. Virgil faces forward and slightly to the right. He bends his head and tilts it to the right. His left arm is bent up at the torso, and his left hand rests palm down on his chest. The head and shoulders of Bocca degli Abbati, a traitor to his hometown of Florence, rise above the surface of the frozen lake in the lower left corner of the design. He faces forward, but turns his head up and slightly to the left, tilting it back as well. His mouth is open, displaying his teeth, and his eyes are wide. His open hands are raised above the ice, palms facing forward. Eight faces and partial bodies of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. The leftmost frozen figure to the right of Virgil’s lower leg faces forward in a horizontal position with the right half of his head and upper body visible above the ice. He appears to have long hair and wear a crown. To his right, a female head with long hair faces forward. Her head is bent to the right. Directly below this pair, a third head is visible facing up and left; this figure is a bearded male with long hair who wears a laurel crown. An indistinguishable form above this head at right may suggest another frozen head. Below the third head at right, a fourth head barely rises above the lake but it faces up and left and wears a crown. In the right corner of the design, three frozen figures are more fully visible, all facing up with heads at right. The lowest of these is a male figure with a mustache and beard who wears a gown and holds a sword in his left hand, which is by his side. Above him, the middle female figure wears a gown and also may hold an object in her left hand, which is by her side. Her head is bent sharply back and her eyes are open wide. The third and highest figure in this group is an old bearded male figure with eyes closed. Above this figure at left, the top half of a forward-facing head rises from the lake. Small shadows appear on the surface of the lake in the lower right corner of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth circle of hell, on a frozen lake that stretches across the bottom of the design.

The base of a rock bridge is visible at the right side of the design, rising from the surface of the frozen lake to the upper right corner of the design. Four petrified or frozen nude human forms appear in the bridge.

Four petrified or frozen nude human forms appear in the rock bridge at right. A figure in the top right corner sits facing forward with eyes closed and mouth open(?). Its head is tilted slightly left and rests on the figure's hands, which are raised on either side of its face, the fingers of the left hand slightly spread. The figure bends forward over bent knees.

Four petrified or frozen nude human forms appear in the rock bridge at right. The leftmost figure, who is gowned, kneels or crouches facing forward and slightly left. He appears to be old and have long hair and a beard. His arms are bent upward with hands clasped together, perhaps in a gesture of prayer or supplication, and tears stream down his face. He may look toward the standing figures at left.

Four petrified or frozen nude human forms appear in the rock bridge at right. In the bottom middle of the bridge, two muscular nude figures lie upside down. The figure at right faces up but bends his head back sharply into the lake below to face forward. He may have long hair and a beard. His legs are raised at a right angle but bent at the knee.

Four petrified or frozen nude human forms appear in the rock bridge at right. In the bottom middle of the bridge, two muscular nude figures lie upside down. The figure at left faces up but bends his head back sharply into the lake below to face forward (and even slightly down). He has long hair. His left arm may be extended horizontally into the lake at left. Both legs are together and extended upward at a right angle.
Dark lines to the left of the rock bridge at the right edge of the design suggests a dark sky, perhaps with clouds, which grows lighter as it approaches the left edge of the design.
A rock or low mound is visible at the left edge of the design, near the lower left corner. This may be stone or frozen ice.
A rock or low mound is visible at the left edge of the design, near the lower left corner. Shadow covers the surface of the lake in the distance to the right of this mound.

In front of the mound at right, a human head appears on the surface of the ice. The head has long hair and closed eyes. It faces forward and leans to the left. Between this head and the mound, there is another round form that is less defined but may suggest a second head or mound.

The two figures of Dante and Virgil stand on the ice at the left side of the design. Dante stands at left in a contrapposto position, facing forward and slightly to the right. He tilts his head to the right and bends it down. His left arm is down by his side, and he holds his left hand very slightly forward, with his vertical palm facing out. His right arm is down and bent forward at the elbow; his open right hand is raised at a right angle with the vertical palm facing out. His feet emerge from beneath the hem of his long gown. He has long hair.

The two figures of Dante and Virgil stand on the ice at the left side of the design. Virgil stands to the right of Dante, who hides him slightly, at the left side of the design. Virgil faces forward and slightly to the right. He bends his head and tilts it to the right. His left arm is bent up at his torso, and his left hand rests palm down on his chest. His eyes are lowered. He has long hair and wears a long gown.

The head and shoulders of Bocca degli Abati, a traitor to his hometown of Florence, rise above the surface of the frozen lake directly below the standing figures of Dante and Virgil. He faces forward, but turns his head up and slightly to the left, tilting it back as well. His mouth is open, displaying his teeth, and his eyes are wide. His open hands are raised above the ice, palms facing forward. His short, curly hair stands on end. He seems to be nude. The ice in front of his torso is cracked.

Eight faces and partial bodies of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. The leftmost frozen figure to the right of Virgil’s lower leg faces forward in a horizontal position with the right half of his head and upper body visible above the ice. He appears to have long hair and wear a crown. His eyes are closed, and his mouth may be slightly open.

Eight faces and partial bodies of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. To his right of the leftmost male head in the center of the composition, a female head with long hair faces forward. Her head is bent to the right with face turned slightly up and to the left. Her eyes are closed.

Eight faces and partial bodies of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. Directly below the highest pair of heads in the center of the composition, a third head is visible facing up and left. This figure is a bearded male with long hair who wears a laurel crown. His eyes are closed. An indistinguishable form above this head at right may suggest another frozen head.

Eight faces and partial bodies of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. Below the third head at right, a fourth head barely rises above the lake but it faces up and left and wears a crown. Its eyes are closed.

Eight faces and partial bodies of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. In the right corner of the design, three frozen figures who float with bodies horizontal are more fully visible, all facing up with heads at right. The lowest of these is a male figure with a mustache and beard who wears a gown and holds the hilt of a sword in his left hand, which is by his side. His left index fingers is extended, pointing left. His eyes are closed and his head is bent back slightly.

Eight faces and partial bodies of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. In the right corner of the design, three frozen figures who float with bodies horizontal are more fully visible, all facing up with heads at right. The middle female figure wears a gown and also may hold an object (perhaps the hilt of a sword?) in her left hand, which is by her side. Her head is bent sharply back and her eyes are open wide.

The frozen male figure in the lower right corner of the composition holds the hilt of a sword in his left hand, extended at his side. The female figure above him may also hold a sword in her left hand, though this object is less clear.

Eight faces and partial bodies of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. In the right corner of the design, three frozen figures who float with bodies horizontal are more fully visible, all facing up with heads at right. The third and highest figure in this group is an old bearded male figure with eyes closed.

Eight faces and partial bodies of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. Above and to the left of the group of three figures in the lower right corner, the top half of a forward-facing head rises from the lake.
Small shadows appear on the surface of the lake in the lower right corner of the design.
